Code Summary: This code implements a symmetry-aware AI system for detecting brain strokes from single CT and MRI slices using a hybrid expert-AI decision framework. The system preprocesses DICOM medical imaging data by normalizing pixel intensities, automatically separating different imaging sequences (T2, FLAIR, DWI, ADC), removing background noise, and applying quantized z-score mapping to highlight lesions. It combines multiple imaging sequences in a 3D analysis approach that mimics radiologist workflow and includes a validation layer for expert review.

Tooling: - DICOM processing capabilities - NumPy for array manipulation - CNN (Convolutional Neural Networks) for image analysis - Custom preprocessing algorithms for sequence separation - Z-score normalization and quantization methods - 3D multi-sequence integration framework

Code Summary: This toolbox implements a "spin test" method for testing anatomical correspondence between cortical surface maps in FreeSurfer or CIVET formats. It provides a robust statistical framework for validating spatial relationships in neuroimaging studies.

The goal is to provide streamlined access to ML tools for researchers to advance PD research, evaluate biomarkers, and identify distinct patient subgroups.
Data Types: Clinical data, behavioral measurements, neurological assessments, population demographics, biomarkers from blood and cerebrospinal fluid, genetic variants, structural and functional brain imaging, olfactory ability tests, depression scores, and mental ability assessments.

Code Summary: This project develops machine learning models to predict Parkinson's disease progression using longitudinal clinical data from the PPMI dataset. The code implements multiple baseline models (Linear Regression, Logistic Regression, Random Forest, XGBoost) that take three consecutive patient visits as input to predict the Hoehn and Yahr scale score for the next visit. The approach focuses on feature selection based on UPDRS (Unified Parkinson Disease Rating Scale) criteria and uses temporal sequences of patient assessments for progression modeling.
Data Types: Clinical assessment data including UPDRS scores, Hoehn and Yahr scale ratings, longitudinal patient visit data with motor examination scores, activities of daily living assessments, and behavioral/cognitive measurements from Parkinson's disease patients.

Biomedical Relevance: YES - This repository is directly biomedically relevant as it focuses on classifying Parkinson's Disease using 3D brain MRI scans. It uses the PPMI (Parkinson's Progression Markers Initiative) dataset and aims to detect neurological patterns associated with Parkinson's Disease progression, which falls squarely within neurodegenerative disease research and brain imaging analysis.
Code Summary: This project implements a deep learning classifier that combines 3D CNNs with self-attention mechanisms to diagnose Parkinson's Disease from structural brain MRI scans. The model uses a 3D CNN encoder to extract spatial features from volumetric brain data, followed by Multi-Head Attention layers to capture global spatial dependencies for binary classification. The system includes utilities for converting DICOM medical images to NIfTI format and achieves performance metrics of 74.1% accuracy and 0.784 ROC AUC.
Data Types: 3D brain MRI scans (structural neuroimaging), DICOM medical images, NIfTI format brain volumes
Tooling: 3D CNN (Conv3D), Multi-Head Self-Attention (MHA), BatchNorm, MaxPooling, TensorFlow/Keras, Binary Cross Entropy Loss, F1 Score metrics, DICOM to NIfTI conversion tools, dropout regularization, class weight balancing

Biomedical Relevance: YES - This repository is biomedically relevant as it implements a brain-computer interface (BCI) system using EEG signals for controlling robotic systems. BCIs are important biomedical applications that can help individuals with neurological conditions or disabilities control external devices through brain activity, particularly useful for patients with motor impairments or paralysis.
Code Summary: This code implements a Steady-State Visual Evoked Potential (SSVEP) based brain-computer interface system that uses OpenVibe for EEG signal processing and ROS for robot control. The system captures EEG signals from visual stimuli at different frequencies (10, 12, 15, 20 Hz), processes them through spatial filtering and classification, and translates the results into control commands for UR5 and Franka Emika Panda robots. The workflow includes training data acquisition, CSP spatial filter training, classifier training, and real-time online control.
Data Types: EEG signals, SSVEP (Steady-State Visual Evoked Potential) data, training datasets with visual stimuli responses at frequencies of 20, 15, 12, and 10 Hz.
Tooling: OpenVibe (signal processing and BCI scenarios), ROS (Robot Operating System), OpenBCI Cyton/Ultracortex EEG headset, CSP (Common Spatial Patterns) filters, TCP socket communication, MoveIt (motion planning), UR5 robot control packages, Franka Emika Panda robot packages, Kinova KG-3 gripper, Kinova K-Series SDK, Ubuntu 16.04, catkin workspace.

This repository is directly focused on biomedical research, specifically analyzing clinical, demographic, and brain-related anatomic measures from human MRI tests to diagnose dementia levels and predict Alzheimer's Disease probability. The approach involves data cleaning, preparation, and comparison of multiple machine learning algorithms to create a model that can provide early alerts for dementia intervention.
Data Types: - Clinical data from MRI tests - Demographic data - Brain-related derived anatomic measures from MRI - Cognitive testing data - Clinical assessments - CDR (Clinical Dementia Rating) labels
Tooling: - Machine learning algorithms (Gradient Boosting, Random Forest, Neural Networks) - K-fold cross-validation - OASIS brain dataset (http://www.oasis-brains.org/) - Binary and multi-label classification frameworks

Code Summary: This project implements a neural network system to predict Alzheimer's disease from MRI brain images using a combination of OASIS1 and ADNI1 datasets. The approach uses three 2D slices from different axes of 3D MRI scans as input to a pre-trained VGG16 network, followed by a deep neural network for final predictions, achieving 76% accuracy and 94% recall.

Biomedical Relevance: YES - This repository is directly relevant to biomedical research as it focuses on brain imaging analysis and neuroimaging data processing. It presents T-PHATE, a manifold learning algorithm specifically designed to analyze fMRI brain data to understand brain state dynamics and neural signatures of higher-order cognition.
Code Summary: This code implements T-PHATE (temporal potential of heat diffusion for affinity-based transition embedding), a multi-view manifold learning algorithm for analyzing brain state trajectories from fMRI data. The repository provides a complete analysis pipeline that applies dimensionality reduction to neuroimaging data, performs event segmentation using Hidden Markov Models, and evaluates how well the learned representations capture static and dynamic properties of brain states during cognitive tasks.
Data Types: fMRI (functional magnetic resonance imaging) data, neuroimaging time series data, movie stimulus labels, localizer stimulus data, behavioral boundary annotations from human raters
Tooling: Python, T-PHATE algorithm package, Hidden Markov Models (HMM), Support Vector Classifier (SVC), conda environment management, SLURM job submission system, dead-simple queue for HPC parallelization, scikit-learn (implied for SVC), numpy/scipy (implied for data processing)

Code Summary: This code implements a Perceiver transformer-based model for binary classification of Alzheimer's disease from sequential brain scan data. The model achieves over 80% accuracy on both validation and test sets for distinguishing between Alzheimer's and non-Alzheimer's brain scans.
